title: Takaaki Kishida
text:
Takaaki Kishida
  


I am a PhD student in Economics at the University of Geneva, Switzerland.
My research interests lie at the intersection of environmental, development, and health economics. In pursuit of generating causally identified and policy-relevant evidence, I employ a variety of data sources, including large surveys, (satellite) remote sensing, and other spatial/GIS data.
In addition, I enjoy working with R and have a strong interest in reproducible research and project management methodologies, which support efficiency and collaboration in research.

 Email: Takaaki.Kishida@unige.ch
CV | Google Scholar | ORCID | GitHub | GitHub Gist | LinkedIn
My name in Japanese: 岸田隆明






Recent News

Publication: Deforestation and Children: Consequences for Paediatric Malaria and Educational Attainment in Indonesia (2024, Journal of Development Studies)  





Other Works

Package 📦: {easysum} Easy-to-use (wrapper) functions for summary statistics in R
Note 📖: Project management
Note 📖: Replication and translation exercises
Shiny App 🗺️: Interactive map of my favorite places in Switzerland
Marathon 🏃: I have completed the Geneva Marathon (May 2025) and am currently training for my next one in 2026.

title: Flexible Regression Outputs with {fixest}
text:
1 Overview

Still under construction.
This note demonstrates flexible regression analyses and table outputs with the {fixest} package.
{fixest} is a fast and flexible package for estimating fixed-effects models.
Main reference: stata2R—fixest.

title: Flexible Regression with {fixest}
text:
Regression

# Reg 1

reg1 <- feols(
  wage ~ educ + age,
  df
)

reg1

OLS estimation, Dep. Var.: wage
Observations: 47,976
Standard-errors: IID 
             Estimate Std. Error  t value   Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) -1340.061  228.55571 -5.86317 4.5708e-09 ***
educ          521.960   14.33997 36.39894  < 2.2e-16 ***
age           277.909    3.72721 74.56229  < 2.2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
RMSE: 8,941.9   Adj. R2: 0.115895

reg1 |> etable()

                               reg1
Dependent Var.:                wage
                                   
Constant        -1,340.1*** (228.6)
educ               522.0*** (14.34)
age                277.9*** (3.727)
_______________ ___________________
S.E. type                       IID
Observations                 47,976
R2                          0.11593
Adj. R2                     0.11589
---
Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

# Reg 2

reg2 <- feols(
  wage ~ educ + age + black + marr | 
    countyfips + year,
  df, 
  vcov = ~countyfips + year
)

reg2

OLS estimation, Dep. Var.: wage
Observations: 47,976
Fixed-effects: countyfips: 50,  year: 3
Standard-errors: Clustered (countyfips & year) 
       Estimate Std. Error   t value  Pr(>|t|)    
educ    455.883    17.5685  25.94881 0.0014818 ** 
age     175.803    55.6531   3.15890 0.0872918 .  
black -1762.725   130.7620 -13.48041 0.0054579 ** 
marr   5510.913   473.3828  11.64156 0.0072980 ** 
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
RMSE: 8,621.1     Adj. R2: 0.177284
                Within R2: 0.175213

reg2 |> etable()

                              reg2
Dependent Var.:               wage
                                  
educ               455.9** (17.57)
age                 175.8. (55.65)
black           -1,762.7** (130.8)
marr             5,510.9** (473.4)
Fixed-Effects:  ------------------
countyfips                     Yes
year                           Yes
_______________ __________________
S.E.: Clustered   by: coun. & year
Observations                47,976
R2                         0.17823
Within R2                  0.17521
---
Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

# Combine the two tables

etable(reg1, reg2)

                               reg1               reg2
Dependent Var.:                wage               wage
                                                      
Constant        -1,340.1*** (228.6)                   
educ               522.0*** (14.34)    455.9** (17.57)
age                277.9*** (3.727)     175.8. (55.65)
black                               -1,762.7** (130.8)
marr                                 5,510.9** (473.4)
Fixed-Effects:  ------------------- ------------------
countyfips                       No                Yes
year                             No                Yes
_______________ ___________________ __________________
S.E. type                       IID   by: coun. & year
Observations                 47,976             47,976
R2                          0.11593            0.17823
Within R2                        --            0.17521
---
Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

title: Flexible Regression Outputs with {fixest}
text:
5 Combine Estimation Results using etable()

# Reg 1
reg1 <- feols(wage ~ educ + age)

# Reg 2: Add FE
reg2 <- feols(
  wage ~ educ + age + black + marr | 
    countyfips + year
)

# Reg 3: Use twoway clustering
reg3 <- feols(
  wage ~ educ + age + black + marr | 
    countyfips + year,
  vcov = ~countyfips + year
)

# Combine the three tables
etable(reg1, reg2, reg3)

                               reg1                reg2               reg3
Dependent Var.:                wage                wage               wage
                                                                          
Constant        -1,340.1*** (228.6)                                       
educ               522.0*** (14.34)    455.9*** (14.82)    455.9** (17.57)
age                277.9*** (3.727)    175.8*** (4.007)     175.8. (55.65)
black                               -1,762.7*** (134.8) -1,762.7** (130.8)
marr                                 5,510.9*** (101.6)  5,510.9** (473.4)
Fixed-Effects:  ------------------- ------------------- ------------------
countyfips                       No                 Yes                Yes
year                             No                 Yes                Yes
_______________ ___________________ ___________________ __________________
S.E. type                       IID      by: countyfips   by: coun. & year
Observations                 47,976              47,976             47,976
R2                          0.11593             0.17823            0.17823
Within R2                        --             0.17521            0.17521
---
Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

A full PDF version of my CV is available upon request.

title: Flexible Regression Outputs with {fixest}
text:
4 Basic Estimation with feols()

4.1 Multiple variables

df |> feols(
  wage ~ educ + age + black + marr
)

OLS estimation, Dep. Var.: wage
Observations: 47,976
Standard-errors: IID 
             Estimate Std. Error   t value   Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)  -950.721  223.15696  -4.26033 2.0452e-05 ***
educ          456.568   13.95431  32.71880  < 2.2e-16 ***
age           175.777    4.01763  43.75147  < 2.2e-16 ***
black       -1763.186  152.17435 -11.58662  < 2.2e-16 ***
marr         5507.951   97.27784  56.62082  < 2.2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
RMSE: 8,639.6   Adj. R2: 0.174619



Note: etable() function is used to display the estimation results in a nice table format.


df |> feols(
  wage ~ educ + age + black + marr
) |> 
  etable()

                feols(df, wage ~ ..
Dependent Var.:                wage
                                   
Constant          -950.7*** (223.2)
educ               456.6*** (13.95)
age                175.8*** (4.018)
black           -1,763.2*** (152.2)
marr             5,508.0*** (97.28)
_______________ ___________________
S.E. type                       IID
Observations                 47,976
R2                          0.17469
Adj. R2                     0.17462
---
Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1




4.2 Multiple fixed effects

df |> feols(
  wage ~ educ + age + black + marr | 
    countyfips + year
)

OLS estimation, Dep. Var.: wage
Observations: 47,976
Fixed-effects: countyfips: 50,  year: 3
Standard-errors: Clustered (countyfips) 
       Estimate Std. Error  t value  Pr(>|t|)    
educ    455.883   14.82402  30.7530 < 2.2e-16 ***
age     175.803    4.00740  43.8695 < 2.2e-16 ***
black -1762.725  134.83084 -13.0736 < 2.2e-16 ***
marr   5510.913  101.57083  54.2568 < 2.2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
RMSE: 8,621.1     Adj. R2: 0.177284
                Within R2: 0.175213




4.3 Clustered standard errors with vcov

df |> feols(
  wage ~ educ + age + black + marr | 
    countyfips + year,
  vcov = ~countyfips + year
)

OLS estimation, Dep. Var.: wage
Observations: 47,976
Fixed-effects: countyfips: 50,  year: 3
Standard-errors: Clustered (countyfips & year) 
       Estimate Std. Error   t value  Pr(>|t|)    
educ    455.883    17.5685  25.94881 0.0014818 ** 
age     175.803    55.6531   3.15890 0.0872918 .

marr   5510.913   473.3828  11.64156 0.0072980 ** 
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
RMSE: 8,621.1     Adj. R2: 0.177284

title: Flexible Regression Outputs with {fixest}
text:
3 Set Dataset Grobally

Set the dataset globally using setFixest_estimation() function so that we don’t need to specify the data argument in the feols() function in each estimation.
In Section 3, we will speficy the data argument in the feols() function to show how it works.
In Section 4 onward, we won’t specify the data argument in the feols() function.


fixest::setFixest_estimation(data = df)

title: Flexible Regression Outputs with {fixest}
text:
6 Multi-Model Estimations

6.1 Split estimation by group

# df |> count(year)
# A tibble: 3 × 2
#    year     n
#   <dbl> <int>
# 1  1974 15992
# 2  1975 15992
# 3  1978 15992

feols(
  wage ~ educ + age + black + marr | 
    countyfips,
  vcov = ~countyfips,
  split = ~year
) |> 
  etable()

                feols(wage ~ edu..1 feols(wage ~ edu..2 feols(wage ~ edu..3
Sample (year)                  1974                1975                1978
Dependent Var.:                wage                wage                wage
                                                                           
educ               425.0*** (23.82)    478.9*** (24.42)    465.5*** (24.31)
age                256.8*** (6.229)    203.0*** (6.948)    66.84*** (7.179)
black           -1,578.9*** (216.2) -1,664.9*** (238.8) -2,059.9*** (288.2)
marr             6,104.4*** (173.0)  5,850.4*** (150.2)  4,582.0*** (174.8)
Fixed-Effects:  ------------------- ------------------- -------------------
countyfips                      Yes                 Yes                 Yes
_______________ ___________________ ___________________ ___________________
S.E.: Clustered      by: countyfips      by: countyfips      by: countyfips
Observations                 15,992              15,992              15,992
R2                          0.25965             0.22264             0.09148
Within R2                   0.25755             0.21946             0.08902
---
Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Management and Coding

title: Project Management
text:
1 Software and Tools

Project management

GitHub (or GitLab) for version controls and effective documentations/management: README, Issues, branches/pull-request, Wiki, and more. Everyone should use them.
GitHub Projects for task management and planning.
Notion or Trello for documentation. Also for planning and task management (when GitHub isn’t needed).

Communication

Always talk in threads for each issue/topic, in the right channel.
Discord: Free
Slack: Better UI (imo) but only last 90-days of messages accessible (so use Discord)
Meeting notes

Avoid Word/GoogleDocs for quick access (requires opening each file to refer to it and doesn’t easily support linking between items).
Notion, GitHub, etc., are better alternatives.


Others

AI tools for coding and writing: GitHub Copilot, Microsoft Copilot, etc.
Econ Paper Search: Search econ papers by journals

title: Project Management
text:
2 General Guideline

2.1 Useful or new
(especially 1-4 are useful)

Matthew Gentzkow

Lab Manual (archived version) see Lab Manual and Appendices in Wiki

Lab Administration
Meeting Notes
JMSLab Notes
Template
Required info for README

GentzkowLabTemplate

Brendan M. Price — Workflow for empirical research
Ricardo Dahis — Template for Empirical Papers
Karl Broman — initial steps toward reproducible research

Everyone should read “Organize your data and code”
Turn repetitive code into functions
Make frequently used functions into a package

emLab — Standard Operating Procedures | repository
Grant McDermott — Data science for economists
Silvia Peracchi — A collection of tips for applied research in Economics
Bergmann, Deer, & Langer (2021) Reproducible Data Analytic Workflows for Economics

Chapter 2 Project Organization

Smith (2023) Reproducible Epidemiology in R — Workflow
Kok (2018) How to keep your research projects organized: folder structure
Office of the AEA Data Editor

Preparing your files for verification
Guidance
A template README for social science replication packages

Bjarkefur, Cardoso de Andrade, Daniels, & Jones (2021) Development Research in Practice: The DIME Analytics Data Handbook

Seminar video (in English) and slides




2.2 Old information (but still nice to see)

Gentzkow & Shapiro (2014) — Code and Data for the Social Sciences: A Practitioner’s Guide
Knittel & Metaxoglou (2018) “Working with Data: Two Empiricists’ Experience” Journal of Econometric Methods, vol.7, no.1

title: Project Management
text:
3 Folder Structure Example
My preferred (basic) structure (you can generate a tree with tree.nathanfriend.com )
.
└── your_project_name/
    ├── data/
    │   ├── processed/
    │   │   ├── building
    │   │   ├── temperature
    │   │   └── main.rds
    │   └── raw/
    │       ├── building
    │       ├── temperature
    │       └── shapefile
    ├── document
    ├── draft/
    │   └── submission/
    │       └── 2024_10_PNAS/
    │           ├── manuscript.tex
    │           └── manuscript.pdf
    ├── output/
    │   ├── figure/
    │   │   ├── figure1_map.pdf
    │   │   ├── figure2A_hist.pdf
    │   │   └── figure2B_binscatter.pdf
    │   └── table/
    │       ├── table1_summarystats.tex
    │       ├── table2_regression_baseline.tex
    │       ├── tableA1_data_list.tex
    │       └── tableB1_regression_falsification.tex
    ├── source/
    │   ├── analysis/
    │   │   ├── figure/
    │   │   │   ├── figure1_map.R
    │   │   │   └── figure2_hist_binscatter.R
    │   │   └── table/
    │   │       ├── table1_summarystats.R
    │   │       ├── table2_regression_baseline.R
    │   │       └── tableB1_regression_falsification.R
    │   ├── data_eda/
    │   │   ├── housing.html
    │   │   └── housing.qmd
    │   └── make_dataset/
    │       ├── make_variables.R
    │       ├── merge.R
    │       └── temperature.R
    ├── README.md
    └── your_project_name.Rproj

title: Project Management
text:
4 Naming Conventions

Read the first few chapters of Boswell and Foucher (2011) The Art of Readable Code
Use consistent case (uppercase or lowercase) and names
Avoid spaces in file/folder names:

Good: make_variables.R, table1_summarystats.tex
Bad: Make New variable.R, Table 1 (new).tex

Variable names

Use prefixes (especially for binary variables) like is_ or has_ to clearly show they hold TRUE / FALSE values.
Avoid ambiguous names:

Good: is_famele, has_renovated
Bad: female, renovation

title: Project Management
text:
5 README

It is better to update regularly to document data sources, dataset construction steps, new files, etc.
Find Economic Articles with Data lists economics papers with replication packages and README files. Reviewing both good and poor examples can be helpful.

title: Project Management
text:
6 R

Always use:

.Rproj
here::here() → means stop using setwd()

Ideally use {targets} and {renv} (for dependency management) (I’m still learning)
Also use a Markdown-like heading structure:

Use Cmd + Shift + R for the first heading (if you like)

Use Quarto to create meeting notes and share intermediate results
The tidyverse team — Tidyverse style guide
Use {fixest} for regression.

For Stata users: stata2R — Regression analysis with fixest
